title: How 2025 E-Fuel Breakthroughs Accelerate Global Synthetic Fuel Scaling in 2026
description:
For years, synthetic fuels were portrayed as futuristic solutions that might one day power planes and ships without fossil emissions.
ReFuelEU Aviation: The SAF Clock Starts In January 2025, Europe’s aviation industry officially entered a new regulatory era through ReFuelEU aviation fuel rules.
The law requires all flights departing from European Union airports to use at least 2% Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF).
At that point, synthetic fuels made from renewable electricity and captured CO₂ will have their own dedicated sub-mandate.
Scaling Synthetic Fuel Production for the 2026 Global Energy Transition The progress recorded throughout 2025 confirms that the era of theoretical decarbonization has ended, giving way to a period of active industrial execution.
text:
In 2025, the conversation around e-fuels transformed from speculation to tangible reality. For years, synthetic fuels were portrayed as futuristic solutions that might one day power planes and ships without fossil emissions. That day arrived sooner than expected.

Governments across Europe, Asia, and the Americas implemented long-awaited climate mandates in 2025. Pioneering companies simultaneously launched the first commercial-scale e-fuel plants. These milestones marked the moment when policy, production, and technology moved in sync.

The shift is critical because e-fuels, produced by combining green hydrogen with captured carbon dioxide, use processes that turn CO₂ into green fuel in a way that can directly replace fossil fuels in hard-to-electrify sectors such as aviation and maritime shipping. Operators can cut emissions using existing infrastructure instead of redesigning entire fleets or energy systems.

Yet challenges remain, especially around cost, feedstock supply, and financing. What 2025 proved is that e-fuels are now operational, not theoretical. What 2026 will determine is whether they can scale fast enough to matter.

Twelve Significant Industrial Milestones in the 2025 E-Fuels Market

1. ReFuelEU Aviation: The SAF Clock Starts

In January 2025, Europe’s aviation industry officially entered a new regulatory era through ReFuelEU aviation fuel rules. The law requires all flights departing from European Union airports to use at least 2% Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF). This sets in motion the first legally binding fuel-blending target of its kind.

SAFs are low-carbon alternatives derived from biological or synthetic sources. The regulation’s most ambitious clause begins in 2030. At that point, synthetic fuels made from renewable electricity and captured CO₂ will have their own dedicated sub-mandate.

Regulations provided airlines and fuel producers with a clear long-term investment trajectory. This certainty allowed financiers to assign predictable value to SAF projects for the first time. Aviation regulations represented a major step toward making e-fuels bankable, even before their specific quotas begin later in the decade, because CO₂-based sustainable aviation fuels are starting to move from pilot projects into commercial contracts.

2. FuelEU Maritime: Shipping’s New Greenhouse Gas Rules Go Live

While aviation captured headlines, 2025 was equally transformative for the maritime sector. The EU’s FuelEU maritime greenhouse gas rules officially came into force on January 1. This regulation requires ships in European waters to reduce the greenhouse gas intensity of their onboard energy by 2%. The initial percentage marks the start of a ratcheting mechanism that will tighten through mid-century, eventually forcing large-scale adoption of low- and zero-emission fuels.

Shipping leaders Maersk and Hapag-Lloyd pioneered the transition by investing in dual-fuel vessels capable of operating on green methanol or ammonia. By combining legal certainty with early commercial success stories, the rule accelerated the business case for green shipping. The rule also positioned Europe as a central hub for alternative maritime fuel development in 2026 and beyond.

3. Kassø: The Commercial-Scale E-Methanol Proof Point

Denmark’s Kassø e-methanol plant achieved a global first in 2025 by launching commercial operations. Beyond serving as a national milestone, the Kassø inauguration validates the global viability of the power-to-liquid model.

The facility achieves significant output through advanced synthesis methods:

Generates 42,000 metric tons of e-methanol annually.

Utilizes renewable power for hydrogen production.

Integrates biogenic CO₂ captured from nearby industrial sources.

Shipping giant Maersk has already contracted the entire volume for its dual-fuel vessels. This partnership proves that large-scale synthesis of carbon-neutral fuels is both possible and profitable. Efficiency, carbon intensity, and cost curves provided by the plant will guide the global e-fuels market as it expands in 2026.

4. ERA ONE: Modular Power-To-Liquids Hits an Operational Milestone

Germany entered the spotlight in 2025 with INERATEC’s ERA ONE facility, Europe’s largest operating e-fuels plant. The site can produce up to 2,500 metric tons of synthetic hydrocarbons per year.

The facility showcases a modular design that allows multiple compact reactors to be deployed efficiently. Each module converts renewable hydrogen and captured CO₂ into synthetic hydrocarbons. These outputs are suitable for use as sustainable fuels or vital chemical feedstocks.

Modular approaches could be transformative for the industry. They lower upfront capital requirements and shorten construction timelines, both major barriers for emerging fuel technologies. ERA ONE demonstrated that e-fuel systems can be built at a smaller, distributed scale before scaling up to industrial capacities. By 2026, INERATEC and its partners plan to replicate this model in additional European regions.

5. Project Roadrunner: A Flagship E-SAF FID and Construction Start

Across the Atlantic, U.S.-based Infinium achieved a significant milestone with the Project Roadrunner facility, which reached its final investment decision (FID) and began construction in 2025. Located in West Texas, the plant aims to produce around 23,000 metric tons—or roughly 7.6 million gallons—of electro-sustainable aviation fuel (eSAF) annually by 2027. Project Roadrunner represents a pivotal shift in North American energy production, far surpassing its annual output figures.

Project Roadrunner demonstrates the financial and technical confidence now emerging in the U.S. e-fuels sector. By combining domestic renewable power resources with captured carbon from industrial sources, the project offers a blueprint for scaling synthetic fuels in regions with favorable energy economics. If completed on schedule, it could make the United States a leader in eSAF production by the late 2020s.

6. Argus E-SAF Indexes: The First Real Price Mirror for Buyers

In late 2025, Argus Media introduced the world’s first eSAF price indexes, establishing the transparency required for institutional maturity. These benchmarks assess regional eSAF prices in Northwest Europe and other hubs, offering investors and off-takers reliable data for contract negotiation. Before these indexes existed, price discovery was opaque, leaving many projects unable to secure financing.

Standardized pricing transformed the market by establishing the transparency required for institutional maturity. Analysts quickly noted a significant price gap in the market. Costs for eSAF were roughly 13 times higher than conventional jet fuel and 3.5 times higher than bio-based SAF. Despite the high price, transparency created a reference framework for subsidies and cost reduction tracking. The data reinforced how economies of scale and cheaper renewable electricity could narrow the gap in the years ahead.

7. The E-SAF Pipeline Reality Check: Cancellations and Delays

Although 2025 brought impressive policy and investment milestones, it also revealed the fragility of the e-fuel supply chain. A comprehensive e-kerosene outlook revealed significant headwinds for the industry. At least 16 large-scale eSAF projects across Europe were paused or canceled by early 2025.

Several critical bottlenecks contributed to these industrial delays:

Inaccessible financing for high-CAPEX projects.

Uncertain long-term CO₂ feedstock supply.

Severe delays in electrical grid connections.

Supply chain obstacles indicate that Europe risks missing 2030 SAF mandates unless production capacity expands immediately. Developers are now focusing on public-private partnerships to bridge the funding gap. With government support increasing and early facilities like Kassø and ERA ONE demonstrating feasibility, 2026 is shaping up to be the make-or-break year for eSAF scalability.

8. ZEMBA: Shipping Demand Pools Turn Into Booked Volumes

By 2025, shipping decarbonization had gained real momentum through coordinated buying power. The Zero Emission Maritime Buyers Alliance finalized a tender that locked in approximately 70,000 tons of e-methanol and 25,000 tons of e-ammonia for delivery beginning in 2027. Companies such as Hapag-Lloyd and NCL participated, showing that the demand side of the market was finally catching up with supply ambitions.

Aggregated purchasing signals maturity within the industry. Instead of fragmented, small-scale trials, global shipping firms are contracting multi-year volumes that enable producers to secure financing. Private-sector collaboration accelerates the energy transition by complementing policy-driven initiatives and aligning with emerging green shipping corridors that test methanol- and ammonia-powered vessels on real trade routes.

9. Maersk: Dual-Fuel Fleets Become the Market’s Metronome

Maersk continued to define the pace of the maritime energy transition in 2025, operating dual-fuel vessels capable of using either traditional fuels or green methanol. Each new delivery added credibility to methanol’s role as a bridge fuel that can immediately reduce lifecycle emissions while e-fuels scale up. The company’s procurement strategy effectively became a market signal for suppliers, port operators, and financiers.

Each Maersk vessel launch drives the development of global port infrastructure, bunkering networks, and standardized fuel protocols. By 2026, analysts expect this fleet to serve as a bellwether for whether e-methanol and e-ammonia can achieve cost parity and availability across global trade routes.

10. Methanol’s Pipeline: Announced Capacity vs. Delivered Reality

The Methanol Institute reported that as of late 2025, there were 252 renewable methanol projects globally, representing more than 45 million tons of announced annual capacity by 2030. However, only a fraction of these are expected to materialize on schedule, given the high capital costs and limited carbon feedstock availability.

This disparity highlights the difference between ambition and execution. While methanol has emerged as the leading candidate for near-term decarbonization in shipping and chemicals, real-world deployments of green methanol as a shipping fuel illustrate how quickly demand grows once supply chains align. In 2026, investors will be watching closely to see which of these projects break ground and which stall at the proposal stage.

11. ANDRITZ Electrolyzer Gigafactory: Scaling the Hardware Layer

In 2025, engineering firm ANDRITZ inaugurated an electrolyzer gigafactory in Erfurt, Germany, with an annual capacity of roughly 1 gigawatt. The Erfurt gigafactory represents a foundational step toward securing the hardware backbone of the hydrogen economy. Electrolyzers split water into hydrogen and oxygen, providing the essential input for e-fuel production.

By increasing production volumes and localizing supply chains, ANDRITZ aims to drive down costs while ensuring component availability for Europe’s rapidly expanding hydrogen projects. The facility’s modular design supports multiple electrolyzer types, including alkaline and PEM systems, allowing for flexibility as technology evolves. This scaling effort lays the groundwork for a green hydrogen supply chain that can reliably feed e-fuel synthesis in the years ahead.

12. Topsoe SOEC Factory: Higher-Efficiency Electrolysis Goes Industrial

Also in 2025, Danish company Topsoe opened the SOEC manufacturing facility in Herning, Europe’s largest solid oxide electrolyzer cell (SOEC) factory. With an initial capacity of 500 megawatts per year and support from the EU Innovation Fund, the site showcases how high-efficiency electrolysis can reduce energy consumption in hydrogen production. SOEC technology operates at higher temperatures, allowing for greater conversion efficiency compared with conventional systems.

Expanding manufacturing capacity drives the economies of scale and technical performance needed to compete directly with fossil fuel pricing. As more factories like this come online, economies of scale and improved performance could accelerate cost parity with fossil fuels.

Critical Commercial Success Factors for Global E-Fuels Growth in 2026

The coming year will test whether the groundwork laid in 2025 can translate into measurable scale. The first metric to watch is final investment decisions (FIDs)—a sign that investors trust both the technology and market conditions. Successful FIDs will unlock construction financing, moving projects from concept to reality.

Identifying Strategic Carbon Feedstocks and Energy Economics

Next, attention will shift to CO₂ sourcing. E-fuels rely on captured carbon, meaning access to affordable CO₂ from biogenic systems will determine production growth. Emerging green ammonia and e-fuel pathways show how fuel molecules and critical mineral supply chains are beginning to converge. Meanwhile, electricity costs remain the largest factor shaping e-fuel competitiveness. Regions with abundant wind and solar power, such as Texas, Chile, and northern Europe, are positioned to lead.

Aligning these strategic factors will enable 2026 to serve as the definitive transition from demonstration projects to genuine commercial scaling. Finally, policymakers will need to ensure that subsidies, contracts-for-difference, and tax credits align to de-risk early projects.

Scaling Synthetic Fuel Production for the 2026 Global Energy Transition

The progress recorded throughout 2025 confirms that the era of theoretical decarbonization has ended, giving way to a period of active industrial execution. With the launch of massive electrolyzer gigafactories and the implementation of binding fuel mandates, the primary hurdles to adoption are shifting from technical feasibility to economic scalability. Corporate leaders and policymakers have successfully demonstrated that the power-to-liquid pathway is viable, creating a roadmap that other regions are already beginning to replicate.

Sustaining Momentum Through Policy and Infrastructure Alignment

As 2026 approaches, the focus moves toward stabilizing supply chains and securing the vast quantities of biogenic carbon required for continuous production. The transition from pilot projects to mainstream energy pillars will require sustained investment and a continued focus on driving down the cost of green hydrogen. If the current trajectory of innovation and policy alignment persists, synthetic fuels will likely become the dominant decarbonizing force for global trade before the end of the decade.

Essential Insights on E-Fuels and Decarbonization

How Are E-Fuels Produced for Industry?

Synthetic fuels are created by synthesizing green hydrogen with captured carbon dioxide to create carbon-neutral liquid energy.

Why Are Synthetic Fuels Vital for Aviation?

Aviation requires high energy density that batteries cannot provide, making drop-in synthetic fuels the most efficient way to lower flight emissions.

What Influences the Current Cost of E-Fuels?

Pricing is primarily dictated by the availability of affordable renewable electricity and the efficiency of electrolyzer hardware used in production.

How Do E-Fuels Differ from Traditional Biofuels?

E-fuels rely on renewable power and carbon capture rather than organic waste, avoiding land-use conflicts and agricultural resource competition.

When Will E-Fuel Mandates Impact Global Markets?

Mandatory blending targets for aviation and maritime sectors began in early 2025, with quotas set to increase significantly toward 2030.

title: HPCL Inaugurates SAF Demonstration Facility at Visakh Refinery |
description:
Hindustan Petroleum Corporation Limited (HPCL) inaugurated a Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) demonstration plant at its Visakh Refinery, marking an important milestone in India’s clean aviation journey.
Advancing India’s SAF Blending Targets With this development, India has taken a decisive step towards achieving its SAF blending targets of one percent by 2027, two percent by 2028, and five percent by 2030.
Alignment with Global Climate Commitments The SAF initiative aligns with the Carbon Offsetting and Reduction Scheme for International Aviation (CORSIA).
Strengthening Energy Self-Reliance and Net-Zero Goals As reported by chinimandi.com, the commissioning of the SAF demonstration plant reinforces India’s energy self-reliance.
By integrating SAF into refinery operations, HPCL is demonstrating how traditional energy infrastructure can adapt to low-carbon pathways.
text:
Hindustan Petroleum Corporation Limited (HPCL) inaugurated a Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) demonstration plant at its Visakh Refinery, marking an important milestone in India’s clean aviation journey. The facility will produce SAF through the co-processing of used cooking oil (UCO) in the refinery’s Full Conversion Hydrocracker Unit, effectively leveraging existing infrastructure and minimising additional capital intensity.

Advancing India’s SAF Blending Targets

With this development, India has taken a decisive step towards achieving its SAF blending targets of one percent by 2027, two percent by 2028, and five percent by 2030. The initiative reflects steady progress in India’s transition to cleaner and more sustainable aviation fuels.

Roadmap for Commercial-Scale SAF Production

The Visakh refinery will begin producing approximately ten thousand metric tons (TMT) of SAF per annum from January 2027, following CORSIA certification. The production will contribute directly to India’s efforts to decarbonise aviation. It will also promote a circular, waste-to-wealth economy by using used cooking oil as a feedstock.

Alignment with Global Climate Commitments

The SAF initiative aligns with the Carbon Offsetting and Reduction Scheme for International Aviation (CORSIA). CORSIA was adopted by the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO). Under CORSIA, airlines must offset emissions exceeding a defined baseline. SAF is a critical tool for long-term emissions reduction in international aviation.

Strengthening Energy Self-Reliance and Net-Zero Goals

As reported by chinimandi.com, the commissioning of the SAF demonstration plant reinforces India’s energy self-reliance. It also supports the country’s broader Net-Zero commitments. By integrating SAF into refinery operations, HPCL is demonstrating how traditional energy infrastructure can adapt to low-carbon pathways.

title: Delta Joins Emirates, American, Lufthansa, Ryanair, Qantas, Turkish, Japan Airlines and ...
description:
Delta Joins Emirates, American, Lufthansa, Ryanair, Qantas, Turkish, Japan Airlines and More to Push Your Air Travel Costs to Record Highs, as 2026 brings a new wave of price surges in the skies.
This shocking price surge is set to continue, fundamentally altering the cost of air travel in 2026 and beyond.
The Role of Airlines in Raising Ticket Prices Airlines are directly responsible for a significant portion of the rising airfare prices.
Many carriers are imposing fuel surcharges, which are adjusted based on fuel prices.
How Airlines Are Justifying Higher Costs Airlines typically justify the rising costs by blaming external factors.
text:
Delta Joins Emirates, American, Lufthansa, Ryanair, Qantas, Turkish, Japan Airlines and More to Push Your Air Travel Costs to Record Highs, as 2026 brings a new wave of price surges in the skies. Delta, Emirates, American, Lufthansa, Ryanair, Qantas, Turkish, Japan Airlines, and several other major airlines are leading the charge by implementing higher fuel surcharges, environmental taxes, and additional fees. These changes are making air travel more expensive than ever before, leaving passengers with little choice but to pay more. The latest update shows how these airlines are using a combination of fuel price volatility, new green regulations, and increased operational costs to justify their fare hikes.

As a result, travelers are facing record-high airfares across the globe, making flying a costly endeavour for many. This shocking price surge is set to continue, fundamentally altering the cost of air travel in 2026 and beyond.

Advertisement

The Surprising Airline Price Wars

Air travel is becoming increasingly unaffordable. As airlines and governments impose various fees, surcharges, and taxes, the cost of flying continues to rise globally. In 2026, passengers are finding themselves facing larger bills for their flights, as airlines pass the cost of fuel, labor, and environmental regulations onto customers. This article explores the various factors behind the dramatic increase in airfares and what it means for travelers.

The Role of Airlines in Raising Ticket Prices

Airlines are directly responsible for a significant portion of the rising airfare prices. Many carriers are imposing fuel surcharges, which are adjusted based on fuel prices. For instance, Delta Air Lines has been charging passengers from Japan hefty fuel surcharges that can add hundreds of dollars to the cost of a ticket. This is not an isolated incident. Emirates, Japan Airlines, and American Airlines are also introducing fuel surcharges that increase flight pricesAirline Fare Research.

One particularly notable example is the Emirates surcharge on flights from Japan, where passengers are expected to pay up to ¥39,500 for certain routesAirline Fare Research. Similarly, Japan Airlines recently updated its fuel surcharges, which vary depending on the destinationAirline Fare Research. These surcharges are added to the base airfare, making the total cost of a ticket much higher than initially expected.

The logic behind these surcharges is simple: airlines are trying to shield themselves from the volatility of fuel prices. When oil prices spike, airlines pass these costs on to passengers, who are left to bear the brunt of unpredictable fuel price fluctuations.

Advertisement

The Growing Green Tax: Environmental Costs and Aviation

As if rising fuel prices weren’t enough, airlines are also being required to comply with stricter environmental regulations. Lufthansa, for example, has introduced an “Environmental Cost Surcharge,” which helps fund sustainable aviation fuel mandates and emissions trading schemes. The fee can range from €1 to €72, depending on the flight’s route and classAirline Fare Research. This green levy is just one example of how environmental regulations are making air travel more expensive.

Similarly, the Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore has introduced a Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) levy that will be applied to flights from Singapore starting in October 2026. The SAF levy will affect both economy and premium cabins, with long-haul passengers being hit hardestAirline Fare Research. These green taxes are seen as necessary for reducing aviation’s environmental impact, but they are also contributing to soaring ticket prices.

Government Taxation: A Hidden Culprit

Governments are also adding their own layers of cost to air travel. The United Kingdom, for example, raised its Air Passenger Duty (APD) in April 2026. The tax now ranges from £32 for short-haul flights to £253 for long-haul flightsAirline Fare Research. This increase in tax is expected to have a significant impact on ticket prices, especially for travelers flying to distant destinations.

Similarly, Canada has increased its Air Travellers Security Charge (ATSC) by as much as 33%Airline Fare Research. This new tax means that passengers will be paying more for security checks when they fly. Although this charge is collected by airlines, it’s an additional burden for passengers who are already grappling with rising base fares and fuel surcharges.

Airlines Get Creative with Fees: The Case of Turkish Airlines

Some airlines are finding new ways to increase revenue without directly raising ticket prices. Turkish Airlines, for example, has introduced a new charge for infant passengers. Previously, infants flying with a parent on their lap would often fly for free or pay a small percentage of the adult fare. Now, Turkish Airlines charges 610 Turkish Lira for domestic flights and 915 Turkish Lira for connecting flightsAirline Fare Research. This seemingly minor fee is a part of the growing trend of airlines monetizing every aspect of air travel, even infant passengers.

Global Comparisons: A World of Rising Prices

Airline fare increases are not limited to any one region. From Australia to Europe and the United States, passengers are facing rising costs. In the U.S., domestic flight prices have increased dramatically for certain city-pair routes. For example, the Austin–Detroit route saw a massive fare hike of 51.5% from $205 to $310Airline Fare Research. Similar increases have been recorded for other routes, with some cities seeing airfare rises of 30% or moreAirline Fare Research.

Even low-cost carriers like Ryanair have raised fares. After a year of cutting prices, the airline saw a 13% increase in average fares for the first half of 2026, a trend that is likely to continue as demand for travel picks upAirline Fare Research.

How Airlines Are Justifying Higher Costs

Airlines typically justify the rising costs by blaming external factors. For example, Ryanair pointed to the costs of environmental taxes and fuel surcharges in explaining its fare increasesAirline Fare Research. Similarly, Qantas cited rising wages, engineering costs, and airport charges as reasons for its higher faresAirline Fare Research. While these reasons are certainly valid, they place the financial burden on passengers, who have little choice but to accept the higher prices.

Is There Any Relief in Sight?

Some airlines have attempted to provide relief to passengers by introducing caps on fares or offering discounts. For example, Air India capped its economy-class fares on non-stop domestic flights following directives from the Indian government to prevent price gougingAirline Fare Research. However, these efforts are relatively rare and do little to offset the broader trend of increasing prices.

The overall message from airlines and governments is clear: passengers should brace for higher ticket prices in the years to come. While some carriers are trying to offer competitive pricing, the global trend is towards rising costs across the board.

Higher Fares Are Here to Stay

As we enter 2026, it’s evident that airfare inflation is not going away anytime soon. Airlines and governments are working in tandem to raise ticket prices through surcharges, taxes, and new levies. Whether it’s the fuel surcharge imposed by Delta, the environmental tax introduced by Lufthansa, or the Air Passenger Duty hike in the UK, passengers will continue to feel the pinch.

In the future, travelers should expect to pay more for their flights and be prepared for hidden fees and charges that are often not disclosed upfront. While some airlines are trying to mitigate costs through discounts or fare caps, the overall trend suggests that airfares will remain high for the foreseeable future.

For passengers planning their travel, the key takeaway is simple: budget for higher ticket prices and keep an eye on additional fees. If current trends continue, flying will only get more expensive, and understanding the complex network of fees and surcharges will become more important than ever before.

title: 80 Mile Share Chat. Chat About 80M Shares - Stock Quote, Charts, Trade History, Share ...
description:
You post - “You’d think shortages would lead to higher SAF prices.” Let's cover the bases in nice simple terms, so that you might grasp it.
The airlines are NOT clambering over themselves in a frenzied need to buy SAF - they'd be quite happy not to have to buy any.
Why would any airline buy SAF when it doesn’t have to?
So while there may be a headline “scarcity” of SAF today, it is a structural and artificial scarcity, not one driven by organic market demand.
Why would airlines have to buy SAF when they don;t have to, exactly.That's where we are at the moment.
text:
RE: UK ​u​likely to have ​h​it the 2025 Sustainable Aviation Fu...Today 07:05

CC - Oh dear, looks like yet another example of you not having a clue about the company / products you are invested in. Your poor / non-existent research and lack of knowledge shines through again. You post -

“You’d think shortages would lead to higher SAF prices.”

Let's cover the bases in nice simple terms, so that you might grasp it.

This is not a normal commodity market where scarcity automatically translates into higher prices. SAF pricing is politically constructed, mandate-driven and subsidy-dependent, not led by demand. The airlines are NOT clambering over themselves in a frenzied need to buy SAF - they'd be quite happy not to have to buy any. Only green-washing and politics might claim otherwise.

Why would any airline buy SAF when it doesn’t have to?

Airlines operate on razor-thin margins. SAF typically costs 2–5× conventional jet fuel. In a competitive industry where fuel is the largest operating cost, voluntarily paying multiples of market price is commercial suicide unless forced to do so. Only a handful of jurisdictions — principally the UK and the EU — currently mandate SAF blending. Much of the rest of the world does not. That creates an immediate and unavoidable distortion:

A non-SAF-using US airline can undercut a UK or EU airline on the same long-haul routes. The US have incentivized SAF usage but it is not mandatory. Figures are targets but by no means compulsory. If economics dictate that it is too costly it won't be used. Will Trump ditch those costly incentives? Drill baby, drill suggests so.

Lower fares win customers.

The “green premium” is not recoverable in ticket pricing.

This is pretty basic stuff - it is not rocket science.

As a result, airlines are reluctant buyers, and when they do buy SAF, they do so grudgingly and opportunistically — often only to the minimum level required for regulatory compliance.

Crucially, airlines are also unwilling to commit to long-term SAF offtake agreements. Why? Because SAF economics are entirely dependent on transient political support: Subsidies, blending credits, tax incentives and mandated targets that can (and do) change with elections and fiscal pressure.

No airline CFO is going to lock into long-term, above-market fuel contracts when the legislative framework underpinning the price can be altered or withdrawn at short notice.

That reluctance feeds directly into the supply side. Without long-term purchase commitments, producers cannot justify the capital investment required to scale SAF production. And without scale, costs don’t come down. Raising prices further only reduces demand even more, making the problem worse, not better.

So while there may be a headline “scarcity” of SAF today, it is a structural and artificial scarcity, not one driven by organic market demand. There is no deep, desperate, cash heavy buyer base waiting to willingly pay higher prices.

Continued............

RE: UK ​u​likely to have ​h​it the 2025 Sustainable Aviation Fu...Today 08:30

Yawn......tell me something I don't know.

Of course it's not a market driven by simple supply and demand.

However, that needs to change and it can change quickly and easiily; but the framework needs to change and IMO it will. Quick enough for 80M shareholders, who knows.

Why would airlines have to buy SAF when they don;t have to, exactly.That's where we are at the moment.

They might start buying it if they can't fly or land their planes without it and I am sorry but we are starting to see signs of that.

RE: UK ​u​likely to have ​h​it the 2025 Sustainable Aviation Fu...Today 13:26

In Europe, the impact of the EU’s Renewable Energy Directive III is starting to be felt, with Germany recently passing draft legislation that should support significantly higher renewable fuel volumes from 2026. “The 2026 renewable volume obligation in the U.S. is also expected to be sharply higher, which should support margins in the country next year,” the analysts said.] End

title: POME-Based Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) as a Game Changer in ... - CME Live Open Access
description:
Abstract Loso Judijanto Palm Oil Mill Effluent (POME) is an underutilized feedstock for sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) production, positioning waste valorization as a game-changing strategy for aviation decarbonization and the implementation of a circular economy.
This qualitative literature review synthesizes recent research (2020-2025) from various journals to evaluate the environmental, technological, economic, and policy dimensions of POME-based SAF.
Indonesia and Malaysia's combined POME generation of 119-178 million metric tons annually creates scalable feedstock potential supporting 360-480 million gallons of SAF production—addressing aviation's primary feedstock scarcity constraint.
Critical challenges include certification integrity (fraud prevention), smallholder inclusion, and potential rebound effects from expanded palm oil cultivation.
Indonesia's emerging SAF roadmap, export restrictions prioritizing domestic value addition, and investment in biorefinery infrastructure position it as a potential global leader in POME-SAF production.
text:
Abstract

Loso Judijanto

Palm Oil Mill Effluent (POME) is an underutilized feedstock for sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) production, positioning waste valorization as a game-changing strategy for aviation decarbonization and the implementation of a circular economy. This qualitative literature review synthesizes recent research (2020-2025) from various journals to evaluate the environmental, technological, economic, and policy dimensions of POME-based SAF. Key findings indicate that POME-derived SAF achieves 65-80% lifecycle greenhouse gas emission reductions compared to conventional jet fuel, with 25-30% of climate benefitsderived from avoided methane emissions through improved wastewater management. Hydrothermal liquefaction and hydro processing pathways demonstrate technical feasibility for compliance with ASTM D7566, while anaerobic digestion remains the most commercially mature conversion route. Indonesia and Malaysia's combined POME generation of 119-178 million metric tons annually creates scalable feedstock potential supporting 360-480 million gallons of SAF production—addressing aviation's primary feedstock scarcity constraint. However, economic viability depends critically on policy support mechanisms, including blending mandates, carbon credits, and cost parity subsidies. Critical challenges include certification integrity (fraud prevention), smallholder inclusion, and potential rebound effects from expanded palm oil cultivation. Indonesia's emerging SAF roadmap, export restrictions prioritizing domestic value addition, and investment in biorefinery infrastructure position it as a potential global leader in POME-SAF production. The analysis concludes that POME-based SAF, through integrated technological optimization, strengthened policy frameworks, and inclusive supply chain development, can meaningfully contribute to aviation's decarbonization while demonstrating circular economy principles at scale.

title: Chinese leasing firm CALC orders 30 Airbus A320neo planes - New Age
description:
China Aircraft Leasing Group Holdings (CALC) and Airbus said Tuesday that the Hong Kong-listed firm had placed an order for 30 A320neo family aircraft.
The firm order, the fifth that CALC has placed with Airbus, brings the total number of aircraft it has ordered from the European aircraft manufacturer to 282, including 203 A320neo family aircraft.
CALC chief executive Mike Poon said in the statement that the order will allow it to ‘continue providing our airline customers worldwide with high-value, modern aircraft solutions’.
The A320neo family is the latest generation of the single-aisle, medium-haul aircraft, offering greater fuel economy and the ability to burn up to 50 per cent sustainable aviation fuel.
Together with Boeing’s 737 family of aircraft, the A320s are the workhorses of the commercial airline industry.
text:
China Aircraft Leasing Group Holdings (CALC) and Airbus said Tuesday that the Hong Kong-listed firm had placed an order for 30 A320neo family aircraft.

The firm order, the fifth that CALC has placed with Airbus, brings the total number of aircraft it has ordered from the European aircraft manufacturer to 282, including 203 A320neo family aircraft.

CALC chief executive Mike Poon said in the statement that the order will allow it to ‘continue providing our airline customers worldwide with high-value, modern aircraft solutions’.

The value of the contract was not disclosed. Airbus has not published list prices for aircraft since 2018. CALC said the aircraft would be delivered through 2033.

As of June the company owned and managed 181 aircraft and counted 41 airlines in 22 countries as clients.

The A320neo family is the latest generation of the single-aisle, medium-haul aircraft, offering greater fuel economy and the ability to burn up to 50 per cent sustainable aviation fuel.

Together with Boeing’s 737 family of aircraft, the A320s are the workhorses of the commercial airline industry.

title: Reflecting on 10 Years of Practicing Ag Law - Precision Farming Dealer
description:
Ten years ago, our law firm opened its doors to try something new.
Rather than focus on one specific area of law or operate a general practice that tried to cover all areas, we decided to focus on a single industry — agriculture.
Ten years ago, agriculture was on the cusp of a digital transformation.
Ten years later, the dust has settled on the ag-tech boom, and yet we have not seen major disruption to ag supply chains.
The practice of law has changed, too.
text:
Ten years ago, our law firm opened its doors to try something new. Rather than focus on one specific area of law or operate a general practice that tried to cover all areas, we decided to focus on a single industry — agriculture. Our clients — farmers, ag-tech providers, and businesses that work in agriculture — were grateful to find lawyers dedicated to their industry. Looking back at how our firm has evolved during the past decade, I see many ways agriculture has changed and how our practice has changed with it.

The business of agriculture has continued to advance. Ten years ago, agriculture was on the cusp of a digital transformation. The ag-tech boom was just beginning, following the ag-data gold rush sparked by Climate Corporation’s sale to Monsanto for nearly $1 billion in 2013. Ag-tech startups were being launched everywhere as Silicon Valley sought to disrupt farming the way it had disrupted brick-and-mortar retailers with internet shopping. Legacy agricultural companies were scrambling to keep pace with ideas from these new startups. Ten years later, the dust has settled on the ag-tech boom, and yet we have not seen major disruption to ag supply chains. Instead, we have seen gradual evolution and improvement to long-standing models, made more efficient by digital tools and connectivity.

Rural America has seen diversification in the landscape from renewable energy projects. Ten years ago, farmland pressures came mainly from urban sprawl and residential development. But now, the Midwest is dotted with renewable projects — wind farms, solar developments, anaerobic digesters producing biogas. The use of corn and soy to create biofuels now includes sustainable aviation fuel (SAF). American farms do not just produce crops; they produce energy.

Livestock farms have continued to survive and thrive. Ten years ago, plant-based “meat” products looked to be rapidly expanding into grocery store shelves. Similarly, alternative “milk” products made with almonds and oats started to expand market share. But a decade and one pandemic later, traditional proteins are having a resurgence, and desire for alt-proteins appears to have stalled. We are especially happy to see our livestock producers doing well and expanding their farming operations.

The practice of law has changed, too. When we started this firm, we felt like we were cutting-edge. No expensive offices, marble floors, mahogany desks, or file rooms filled with paper. Instead, we operated with laptops, cell phones, cloud-based software, and modest but modern accommodations provided in a building full of ag commodity groups (thanks, Jane Ade Stevens). We were ahead of the curve in creating a streamlined office environment.

While there have been many changes to both agriculture and the practice of law in the past ten years, the core of our business has remained the same. That core focus is on building human relationships. More than anything, after ten years, I am grateful for those relationships — clients, co-workers, friends, and family — that have helped make us successful. Here’s to ten more years!
